G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the damages exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to the cause of action occurred in Worcester, Massachusetts.

Worcester City Ordinance, Chapter 12, Se.proposition: Pursuant to Worcester City Ordinance, Chapter 12, Section 35 and G.L. c. 84, § 1, Defendant is obligated to clear snow and ice from the sidewalk adjoining her property to ensure it is safe for use.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 1.proposition: Pursuant to Worcester City Ordinance, Chapter 12, Section 35 and G.L. c. 84, § 1, Defendant is obligated to clear snow and ice from the sidewalk adjoining her property to ensure it is safe for use.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to maintain the sidewalk adjoining 123 Maple Street in a reasonably safe condition, free of hazards such as snow and ice, and to comply with applicable laws and ordinances governing snow and ice removal.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns a fall in a privately owned mall parking lot under premises liability, and it abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, imposing a general duty of reasonable care for snow and ice on a landowner’s own premises. The claimed proposition, however, refers to a duty to maintain a sidewalk ‘adjoining 123 Maple Street’ and to comply with ‘applicable laws and ordinances’ governing sidewalk snow removal—issues that sound in abutting‑landowner/sidewalk/public way law and in statutory or ordinance-based duties, which this opinion expressly distinguishes and does not decide. Thus, the case supports a general reasonable-care duty as to snow and ice on the owner’s property, but not specifically a duty to maintain an adjoining sidewalk or to comply with municipal snow-removal ordinances.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’ … Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable…. The snow removal reasonably expected of a property owner will depend on the amount of foot traffic… the magnitude of the risk… and the burden and expense of snow and ice removal.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre- and post-judgment interest as allowed by law pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and § 6C.

\u00a7 6C.proposition: Pre- and post-judgment interest as allowed by law pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and § 6C.
